results.title: Carpark
results.brief_description: Moorabbin - The shopping mall is now a permanent fixture of our suburban landscapes. Carpark consists of multiple scenes of shopping, parking and just hanging-out juxtaposed against an aural collage of people talking about their experience of mall culture. This is a superbly crafted short experimental work that will resonate with each and every one of us who has spent time ‘down at the Mall’. Carpark was made over a weekend in the carpark of Southland shopping centre.

results.title: Lights, camera, action: Supergeek (August 2006)
results.brief_description: In this story the ACMI Screen Pit becomes a Sunridge High classroom. Oscar from Short Cuts is auditioning for roles in his latest film ‘Super Geek 2’. He tries to get the Short Cuts kids to do it but has no luck, so he turns to the ‘new class’ for help. Produced in Melbourne and screened on the Seven Network, Short Cuts is a terrific local TV series set in a Year 9 Media Studies class. Short Cuts’ stories explore how the video camera can be a tool of expression, exploration and communication - and also of manipulation, secrecy and lies. Slowly, the characters find ways of using the camera and in the process, find out more about themselves, each other, their friends, their families and the world.

results.title: Murder on the dance floor (July 2006)
results.brief_description: A blood chilling murder mystery set at a high school formal. This green screen workshop was produced as part of the G.A.T.E.ways (gifted and talented education) program for kids. The year 6 students learnt scripting, production and performance skills using virtual set technology.

results.title: Back to the past (April 2006)
results.brief_description:
“Back to the Past” is a program for primary schools to learn scripting, production and performance skills using virtual set technology. Starring Charles “Bud Tingwell ” as a time travelling scientist, BTTP sends students back in time to historical Melbourne using archival footage, animation and green screen technology.
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
